In non FMD-endemic countries, a critical component of any outbreak response is a process known as backward and forward tracing, essentially working out who an infected individual has had contact with during their infectious period
15 . Early in the response to large-scale outbreaks, when contact-tracing is just getting underway, the implementation of appropriate interventions is time-critical
16 . At this early stage in an outbreak, when appropriate interventions can have the most impact, laboratory and field resources are often pushed to their limit
17 . Important decisions must be made under considerable uncertainty and in conditions that are continually evolving. Central questions for the outbreak investigation team are ‘who infected whom?’, ‘who will be infected next?’ and ‘how and where should we intervene?’
18 . Answering these questions in time to inform decision-makers can lead to large potential savings through better targeting who to investigate and which farms to quarantine, and/or depopulate or vaccinate.
